intro: Purshia plicata, commonly known as the golden-scurf grass, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, which includes legumes, and is characterized by its compound leaves and yellow flowers. The plant is adapted to arid environments, with deep roots that help it survive in dry conditions. Its flowers are typically arranged in clusters and bloom in the spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The plant's seeds are enclosed in pods and can remain viable in the soil for several years.
